Course Description: This course will discuss some fundamental aspects of ecological, evolutionary, genetic, and epidemic models as studied by quantitative approaches. Simple mathematical and computational tools will be taken up to carry out quantitative analysis of biological systems. In addition, students will be introduced to MATLAB. Assignments and project work will include quantitative study and data analysis for biological processes (using MATLAB).

Prerequisites.Mandatory: Basics of calculus and linear algebra(MTH100)

Course Outcomes.CO1: An ability to build model for biological systems from evolution and ecology
Course Outcomes.CO2: Some knowledge of constructing quantitative models like differential and difference equation for a given biological problem and implementing solving methods
Course Outcomes.CO3: Some proficiency in using MATLAB to solve biological problems numerically
Course Outcomes.CO4: An ability to utilize the knowledge gained from this course in more advanced topics

Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Quantitative exercise: Use matlab to get cobweb plots
Quantitative exercise: Use matlab to solve projection matrices and make inferences from it
Quantitative exercise: Use matlab solve ODE
Quantitative exercise: Use matlab to solve probabilistic models of DNA evolution
Quantitative exercise: Use matlab to construct phylogentic tress
Quantitative exercise: Use matlab to solve simple epidemic models

Resource Material.Textbook: Mathematical model in biology: an Introduction by ELIZABETH S. ALLMAN and JOHN A. RHODES
Resource Material.Reference Book: Essential Cell Biologyby Bruce Alberts, Dennis Bray, Karen Hopkin, Alexander D Johnson, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, Peter Walter(Garland Science)
